SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

NO. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who has lived in Western Canada can experience as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to you; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. If you're unable to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or supply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Flat: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ). One will be sent to you at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

All Questionnaires

- Pioneer health conditions and recreation
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and places names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you have any other information about your experiences, please give it.

1. Your full name ...............................................................

2. Your address ...............................................................

3. Date ...............................................................

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)

5. What was your father's name and occupation?

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use I was a small child, in any event, etc.)

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

were there free land available in the west (homestead)

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people! Reading about it?)

Railroad or government information?

REPRINTED FROM GOVERNMENT INFORMATION.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

THEY THOUGHT IT WAS A GOOD IDEA.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends)?

With a group of relatives and friends.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Railroad to the nearest town, then by horses and oxen to our homestead which was about twenty miles from town.

14. What incidents of the journey do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures, etc.)

NONE

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

At a new town called Wedena.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

SW 30-35-9 W4 and SW 32-35-9 W4 Town of Wedena.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

On our homestead in the district of Lintleaw from 1905 to 1918. The railroad arrived in the district in 1920 and at that time we settled in the new town of Lintleaw and have continued to reside in the Village ever since.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Worked in a cotton factory at Vancouver, B.C., for 4 years. Prior to that worked in factories in Murray, Montana, where my husband farmed from 1905 to 1919. Then obtained a store and postoffice for the village of Wedena for some years, then disposed of the store and was postmaster until his death in 1937. After that I have retired & live by myself.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends)?
   With a group of relatives and friends

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   Railroad to the nearest town, then by horse and oxen to our homestead, which was about twenty miles from town.

14. What incidents of the journey to Western Canada do you remember? (Experiences on the trail, meetings in Indian camps, etc.)
   None

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   At a new town called Madena.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   SW 30-35-9 W4

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   On our homestead in the district of Lintlaw from 1905 to 1918. The railroad arrived in the new town of Lintlaw and we continued to reside in the village ever since.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
   For 4 years prior to that I worked in factories... After coming west my husband farmed from Murray, Alberta, where he had a store and post office from 1905 to 1919. Then we moved to some place near Murray, Alberta, and were farmers until his death in 1937. Since that time I have acted as his helper.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

About 4 times a year

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Married to Marian Brenne on June 11, 1898 at Murray

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

None

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

None

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to relate?

My first homestead in my memory was located in 1905, words out from town by horse, I took two days' travel to make the trip, which meant that we had to lodge out nights along the trail, many times had to climb miles along water along to make a mile or so. It took a team to arrive or our homestead lot stack the afternoon day.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting relatives, etc.)

Not very often

My husband was sometimes held in our house, my stepfather would travel to town about once a month. As I had small children I did not go to town as the trip was too hard.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

About 4 times a year.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Married to Maria Bemtine on June 11, 1895.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation it as a place to settle?

No

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

None

23. In what way did the experiences of pioneer days stand out in your mind?

My first experience was coming out to our homestead in 1885. We traveled from my home by horse, taking two days to get there. We had to make the journey without much money, which made it hard to provide for ourselves. We faced many trials and challenges during our travels, but we arrived at our homestead by March after a long day.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.)

Not very often.

My husband would travel to town about once a month. As I had small children I did not go to town as the trip was too hard.
25. When was the first car used in the community? 1919

In 1910 we used mail orders.

We purchased clothing by mail orders as we had very little money at most times.

was used for groceries & food.

Yes, we had made the decision by then.

January 4, 1919.

We purchased clothing by mail order as a very small percentage by mail order as we had very little money so a more formal dress was used for special occasions.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1910? What reasons did they have for moving?

Very few.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

My husband was Postmaster at Vintlaw from 1910 until 1937 at which time he died. He was also a school trustee + town councillor for quite a number of years.

Was first Postmaster at Vintlaw from 1910-1937.

One first school trustees of Vintlaw elected 1909.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organization, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combining organizing the first lodge, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (1) Name Vintlaw was first used for the school in 1909 also for the postoffice in 1910 which was located on our farm. In 1919 this town plus our community was named Vintlaw.

The name Vintlaw was suggested by John McElhenny who farmed in the community.

(2) Believe it is a word name meaning flex

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? What reasons did they have for moving?

Very few.

35. Did any people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

My husband was Postmaster at Vintlaw from 1910 until 1937 at which time he died. He was also in Paul Taylor's insurance business from 1918 to 1937. Also a school trustee & town councilman for quite a number of years.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organization, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My husband was Postmaster at Vintlaw from 1910 until 1937 at which time he died. He was also in Paul Taylor's insurance business from 1918 to 1937. Also a school trustee & town councilman for quite a number of years.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "firsts" to have or do something in the district mention it here, giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combining organizing the first lodge, etc.)

Was first Postmaster in Vintlaw from 1910-1937

(1) Name Vintlaw was first used for the school in 1909 also in the post office in 1910 which was located on my farm. In 1919 the town of our community was named Vintlaw.

The name Vintlaw was suggested by John McAllister who farmed in the community.
